[[English language|English]], [[History]] (1978) | alma_mater = [[Cornell University]] | active = 1979–present | genre = [[Political satire|Political]]/[[news satire]], [[observational comedy]], [[cringe comedy]], [[black comedy]], [[insult comedy]], [[sarcasm]] | subject = Mass media/news media/media criticism, American politics, American culture, current events, religion, pop culture, race relations, human sexuality | influences = | influenced = | website = {{url|billmaher.com}} }} '''William Maher''' ({{IPAc-en|m|ɑːr}}; born January 20, 1956) is an American comedian, political commentator, and television host. He is known for the [[HBO]] political talk show ''[[Real Time with Bill Maher]]'' (2003–present) and the similar [[Late night television in the United States|late-night]] show called ''[[Politically Incorrect]]'' (1993-2002), originally on [[Comedy Central]] and later on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]. Maher is known for his sarcastic attitude,{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qxa5uj95B84C&pg=PA87 |title=American Scream: The Bill Hicks Story |first=Cynthia |last=True |publisher=HarperCollins |year=2002 |isbn=9780380803774 |page=87}} [[political satire]], and [[sociopolitical]] commentary. He targets many topics including religion, politics, bureaucracy, [[political correctness]], and the mass media.{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4792262|title=Political Satirist Bill Maher's 'New Rules'|publisher=[[NPR]]|accessdate=January 23, 2011 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110219031226/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4792262| archivedate= February 19, 2011 | deadurl= no}} Maher supports the legalization of cannabis and same-sex marriage. His critical views of religion were the basis for the 2008 documentary film ''[[Religulous]]''. He is a supporter of [[animal rights]], having served on the board of [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]] since 1997,{{cite news |title=Bill Maher: 25 Things You Don't Know About Me|date=January 23, 2015|author=US Weekly Staff|work=[[Us Weekly]]|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/bill-maher-25-things-you-dont-know-about-me-2015231}} and is an advisory board member of [[Project Reason]].{{Cite news| title = Interview with Larry King, 9-28-03| url = http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0308/28/lkl.00.html| quote = Larry, I'm a PETA board member.| work=CNN}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20100608062154/http://www.project-reason.org/about/advisory_board The Reason Project]; Project Reason.org; 2011 In 2005, Maher ranked at number 38 on [[Comedy Central]]'s 100 greatest stand-up comedians of all time.{{cite web|url=http://www.comedycentral.com/tv_shows/100greatest/list.jhtml |title="Comedy Central's Top 100" |accessdate=2005-04-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050404175840/http://www.comedycentral.com/tv_shows/100greatest/list.jhtml |archivedate=April 4, 2005 |df=mdy }}. Comedy Central. April 4, 2005 He received a [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] star on September 14, 2010.{{Cite news|title = Bill Maher gets Hollywood Walk of Fame star, September 14, 2010|url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2010-09-14-maher-hollywood-star_N.htm|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=September 14, 2010}} {{TOC limit|3}} ==Early life== Maher was born in New York City. His father, William Aloysius Maher Jr., was a network news editor and radio announcer, and his mother, Julie Maher (née Berman), was a nurse.{{cite web|url = http://www.filmreference.com/film/32/Bill-Maher.html |title = Bill Maher Biography (1956–) |publisher = Film Reference |accessdate = January 17, 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080108083123/http://www.filmreference.com/film/32/Bill-Maher.html| archivedate= January 8, 2008 | deadurl= no}} He was raised in his Irish-American father's Roman Catholic religion. Until his early teens, he was unaware that his mother, whose family was from Hungary,{{cite web|url=http://www.dead-frog.com/comedians/comic/bill_maher|title=Bill Maher|work=Dead-Frog|accessdate=April 10, 2013|quote= Part Hungarian part Irish...}} was Jewish.{{cite news |url = http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0205/24/lkl.00.html|title=Interview With Bill Maher |date=May 24, 2002 |publisher = CNN |accessdate=January 17, 2008|quote= My mother is Jewish. But I never even knew I was half-Jewish until I was a teen-ager.}}{{cite web|date=November–December 2008 |last= Carlin-McCall|first= Kelly|url= http://www.irishabroad.com/irishworld/irishamericamag/octnov08/features/bill-maher-octnov08.asp|title= The Real Bill|publisher= [[Irish America magazine]]|accessdate= April 23, 2010|quote= So the fact that I'm half Irish and half Jewish, they both contributed to a sense of humor.}}{{cite news|date=July 2011|last= Morgan|first= Piers|url= http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2011/07/12/maher-on-religion/|title= Bill Maher explains his 'apatheism,' apathetic atheism|publisher= CNN|accessdate= July 12, 2011|quote= ... and I was raised Catholic. I was never Jewish}} Owing to his disagreement with the Catholic Church's doctrine about birth control, Maher's father stopped taking Maher and his sister to Catholic church services when Maher was thirteen.{{cite web|url=http://media.www.diamondbackonline.com/media/storage/paper873/news/2008/10/03/Diversions/Getting.Blasphemous.In.The.Presence.Of.Bill.Maher-3467097.shtml |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221013449/http://media.www.diamondbackonline.com/media/storage/paper873/news/2008/10/03/Diversions/Getting.Blasphemous.In.The.Presence.Of.Bill.Maher-3467097.shtml |archivedate=2008-12-21 |title=Getting Blasphemous in the Presence of Bill Maher |publisher=Media.www.diamondbackonline.com |accessdate=October 18, 2010}} Maher was raised in [[River Vale, New Jersey]], and graduated from Pascack Hills High School in [[Montvale, New Jersey|Montvale]] in 1974. He then attended [[Cornell University]], where he double majored in English and history, and graduated in 1978.{{cite web |url=http://www.comcast.net/slideshow/entertainment-ivyleague/29/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140812031553/http://www.comcast.net/slideshow/entertainment-ivyleague/29/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 12, 2014 |title=Entertainment; Ivy League Celebrities |publisher=Comcast.net |accessdate=November 7, 2011 }} Maher has said: "selling pot allowed me to get through college and make enough money to start off in comedy."[http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2013-09-05/bill-maher-how-did-i-get-here Bill Maher: How did I get here?]; Bloomberg BusinessWeek; September 5, 2013; Real Life with Bill Maher, November 7, 2014. ==Career== ===Early career=== Maher began his career as a comedian and actor. He was host of the New York City [[comedy club]] [[Catch a Rising Star (comedy clubs)|Catch a Rising Star]] in 1979. Maher began appearing on [[Johnny Carson]]'s and [[David Letterman]]'s shows in 1982.[http://projects.latimes.com/hollywood/star-walk/bill-maher/ Bill Maher - Hollywood Star Walk]; ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''; Patrick Kevin Day; September 13, 2010 He made limited television appearances including on ''[[Sara (U.S. 1985 TV series)|Sara]]'' (1985),{{cite news|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Bill Maher Filmography|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movies/person/44630/Bill-Maher/filmography|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150620224945/http://www.nytimes.com/movies/person/44630/Bill-Maher/filmography|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2015-06-20}} ''[[Max Headroom (TV series)|Max Headroom]]'' (1987),''Science Fiction, Horror & Fantasy Film and Television Credits: Television shows''; Harris M. Lentz; McFarland Publishing, 2001; Pg. 1944 ''[[Murder, She Wrote]]'' (1989, 1990), and ''[[Charlie Hoover]]'' (1991). His feature film debut was in ''[[D.C. Cab]]'' (1983). He later appeared in ''[[Ratboy]]'' (1986), ''[[House II: The Second Story]]'' (1987), ''[[Cannibal Women in the Avocado Jungle of Death]]'' (1988), and ''[[Pizza Man]]'' (1991). ===Television career=== [[File:SethMcFarlaneBillMaherSept10.jpg|thumb|[[Seth MacFarlane]] speaking at a ceremony for Maher to receive a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] in September 2010]] ====''Politically Incorrect with Bill Maher''==== {{Main|Politically Incorrect}} Maher assumed the host role on ''Politically Incorrect with Bill Maher'', a late-night political talk show that ran on Comedy Central from 1993 to 1997 and on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] from 1997 to 2002. The show regularly began with a topical monologue by Maher preceding the introduction of four guests, usually a diverse group of individuals, such as show business, popular culture, political pundits, political consultants, authors, and occasionally news figures. The group would discuss topical issues selected by Maher, who also participated in the discussions.{{Cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/27/arts/television-lots-of-political-humor-and-no-morton-kondracke.html?n=Top/Reference/Times%20Topics/People/M/Maher,%20Bill |title = TELEVISION; Lots of Political Humor, and No Morton Kondracke|date = February 27, 1994 |newspaper = The New York Times | first=Bill| last=Carter |accessdate = August 9, 2010}} [[Jerry Seinfeld]], a regular guest on the show, stated that ''Politically Incorrect'' reminded him of talk shows from the 1950s and '60s "when guests interacted with each other as much as with the host". ''Politically Incorrect'' won an array of awards, including an [[Emmy Award]] for Outstanding Technical Direction, two [[CableACE]] awards for Best Talk Show Series, and a [[Genesis Award]] for Best Television Talk Show. Maher earned numerous award nominations for his producing, writing, and hosting of ''Politically Incorrect'', including ten [[Emmy]] nominations, two [[TV Guide]] nominations, and two [[Writers Guild of America|Writers Guild]] nominations. ABC decided against renewing Maher's contract for ''Politically Incorrect'' in 2002, after he made a controversial on-air remark six days after the [[September 11 attacks]].{{cite web|url=http://thebigstory.org/ov/ov-politicallyincorrect.html |title=The Big Story: Politically Incorrect |accessdate=June 19, 2007 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070713120522/http://thebigstory.org/ov/ov-politicallyincorrect.html| archivedate= July 13, 2007 | deadurl= no}} He agreed with his guest, conservative [[pundit (expert)|pundit]] [[Dinesh D'Souza]], that the 9/11 terrorists did not act in a cowardly manner (in rebuttal to [[George W. Bush|President Bush]]’s statement calling them cowards). Maher said, "We have been the cowards. Lobbing cruise missiles from 2,000 miles away. That's cowardly. Staying in the airplane when it hits the building. Say what you want about it. Not cowardly. You're right." Maher later clarified that his comment was not anti-military in any way whatsoever, referencing his well-documented longstanding support for the American military.{{Cite book|last=Goldberg |first=Danny |authorlink= |title=It's a Free Country: Personal Freedom in America After September 11 |publisher=RDV Books |year=2002 |page=77 |isbn=0-9719206-0-5}}{{Cite news |last=Garofoli |first=Joe |title=Talk host's towering rant: S.F. not worth saving |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2005/11/11/MNGFMFMNV41.DTL |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=October 9, 2007 |postscript= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071102175526/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=%2Fc%2Fa%2F2005%2F11%2F11%2FMNGFMFMNV41.DTL |archivedate=November 2, 2007 |deadurl=no |df=mdy-all }} After receiving complaints, [[FedEx]] and [[Sears|Sears Roebuck]] pulled their advertisements from the show, costing the show significant revenue.{{Cite news |last=Navasky |first=Victor |title=Profiles in Cowardice |url=http://www.thenation.com/doc/20011105/navasky |newspaper=[[The Nation]] |accessdate=October 9, 2007 |postscript= |archiveurl=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20090630183528/http%3A//www%2Ethenation%2Ecom/doc/20011105/navasky |archivedate=June 30, 2009 |deadurl=no |df=mdy-all }}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZjnUyVhccr4C&pg=PA389 |title=Entertainment and Society: Influences, Impacts, and Innovations |last=Sayre |first=Shay |last2=King |first2=Cynthia |publisher=Taylor & Francis |year=2010 |edition=2 |isbn=9780203882931 |accessdate=2013-04-19}} Maher's remarks after 9/11 were not the first time he had sparked controversy on ''Politically Incorrect''. In the same year, he expressed his deep regrets and apologized after being widely criticized for comparing his dogs to retarded children.{{Cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/01/18/us/tv-host-s-words-draw-criticism-and-apology.html | work=[[The New York Times]] | title=TV Host's Words Draw Criticism and Apology | date=January 18, 2001 | accessdate=April 1, 2010}} The show was canceled on June 16, 2002, and the [[Sinclair Broadcast Group]] had dropped the show from its [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]-[[Network affiliate|affiliated]] stations months prior. On June 22, 2002, just six days after the cancellation of ''Politically Incorrect'', Maher received the Los Angeles Press Club president's award (for "championing free speech"). Maher was on the board of judges for the 2002 [[PEN/Newman's Own First Amendment Award]].Siems, Larry (April 11, 2002). [http://www.pen.org/press-release/2002/04/11/vanessa-leggett-receive-2002-pennewmans-own-first-amendment-award "Vanessa Leggett to receive 2002 PEN/Newman's Own First Amendment Award"]. Pen American Center. ====''Real Time with Bill Maher''==== {{Main|Real Time with Bill Maher}} In 2003, Maher became the host, co-producer, and co-writer of ''Real Time with Bill Maher'', a weekly hour-long political comedy talk show on the cable television network [[HBO]]. In 2016, HBO renewed ''Real Time'' through 2018, for its 15th and 16th seasons.{{cite news|last1=Prudom|first1=Laura|title=‘Real Time With Bill Maher’ Renewed Through 2018|url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/real-time-with-bill-maher-renewed-season-15-16-1201827123/|accessdate=August 1, 2016|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=30 July 2016}} During an interview, Maher told [[Terry Gross]] (on NPR's ''[[Fresh Air]]'') that he much prefers having serious and well-informed guests on his program, as opposed to the random celebrities that fleshed out his roundtable discussions on ''Politically Incorrect''.{{Cite news| url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4490632 | work=NPR | title=Bill Maher: Four More Years | date=February 8, 2005 | accessdate=August 9, 2010}} As with his previous show, ''Politically Incorrect'', Maher begins ''Real Time'' with a comic opening monologue based upon current events and other topical issues. He proceeds to a one-on-one interview with a guest, either in-studio or via satellite. Following the interview, Maher sits with two or three panelists, usually consisting of [[pundit (expert)|pundits]], authors, activists, actors, politicians, and journalists, for a discussion of the week's events. ''Real Time'' has earned widespread praise. It has been nominated for more than ten Primetime [[Emmy Awards]] and six [[Writers Guild of America|Writer's Guild]] awards. In 2007, Maher and his co-producers were awarded the Television Producer of the Year Award in Variety Television by the Producers Guild of America.[http://www.producersguild.org/?page=PGA_Award_19902010&hhSearchTerms=PGA+and+Award+and+Winners+and+1990-2010 Producers Guild of America Awards – Winners 1990-2010]; PGA.org; May 29, 2012 Maher holds the record for the most Emmy nominations without a win, having been nominated on 22 occasions and not winning once. Eleven of the nominations were for ''Politically Incorrect'', while nine were for ''Real Time''. The other two were nominations for two of his HBO comedy specials: ''[[I'm Swiss]]'' and ''[[Bill Maher: The Decider]]''.{{Cite news| url=http://goldderby.latimes.com/awards_goldderby/2009/07/will-emmys-biggest-loser-bill-maher-ever-win.html | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Gold Derby | date=July 20, 2009}} =====Notable responses to ''Real Time'' episodes===== In late May 2005, Alabama Congressman [[Spencer Bachus]] sent a letter to [[Time Warner]]'s board of directors requesting ''Real Time'' be canceled after remarks Maher made after noting the military had missed its recruiting goals by 42 percent. Bachus said he felt the comments were demeaning to the military and treasonous. Maher stated his highest regard and support for the troops and asked why the congressman criticized him instead of doing something about the recruitment problem.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,157435,00.html |title=Bill Maher's Remark About Army 'Borders on Treason,' Lawmaker Says – Celebrity Gossip |publisher=FOX News |date=May 23, 2005 |accessdate=October 18, 2010}} On September 17, 2010, Maher aired a clip of Delaware [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Senatorial candidate [[Christine O'Donnell]] from the October 29, 1999 episode of his old show ''Politically Incorrect'' on his current show ''Real Time with Bill Maher'',{{cite news| last = McGreal| first = Chris| title = Christine O'Donnell: I dabbled in witchcraft| date = September 20, 2010| work = The Guardian | location = London| url =https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/sep/20/christine-o-donnell-dabbled-witchcraft| accessdate = September 20, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100922011030/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/sep/20/christine-o-donnell-dabbled-witchcraft| archivedate= September 22, 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/bs-ae-arts-story-1119-20101118,0,6769640.story|title=Bill Maher celebrates the art of standup|first=Michael|last=Sragow |newspaper=The Baltimore Sun}} where she mentioned that she had "dabbled in witchcraft". This was one of the most notable of numerous controversial statements by O'Donnell that made her the most covered candidate in the 2010 mid-term election cycle.[http://www.journalism.org/numbers_report/midterms’_media_mainstays The Midterms' Media Mainstays | Project for Excellence in Journalism (PEJ)]{{cite news |url=http://watching-tv.ew.com/2010/09/19/christine-odonnell-witchcraft-bill-maher|title=Christine O'Donnell, witchcraft, and Bill Maher: TV and politics put a hex on common sense|author=Ken Tucker|work=Entertainment Weekly}} In February 2017, Maher invited [[Milo Yiannopoulos]] to be interviewed on ''Real Time.'' Yiannopoulos accepted, despite protests from some commentators and fans. The appearance on Maher's show harmed Yannopoulos's career due to comments in the interview where he seemed to express sympathy toward perpetrators of child sexual abuse. In the days following the interview, Yiannopoulos had his invitation to speak before the 2017 [[Conservative Political Action Conference]], as well as a book deal with [[Simon & Schuster]], cancelled. Yiannopoulos subsequently resigned as an editor at [[Breitbart News]]. When asked whether Yiannopoulos's interview on his show was among the causes of his resignation, Maher concurred, saying, "As I say, sunlight is the best disinfectant. You're welcome."{{cite news |first=Dave|last=Itzkoff|work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/22/arts/television/bill-maher-milo-yiannopoulos-interview.html|title=Bill Maher, Faulted for Booking Milo Yiannopoulos, Takes Credit for His Fall |date=February 22, 2017 |accessdate=February 22, 2017}} Later in June 2017, Maher came under criticism for saying "I'm a [[house nigger]]" on Real Time with calls being made by people to HBO to fire him.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/jun/03/bill-maher-hbo-real-time-ben-sasse|title=Bill Maher sorry for use of N-word as HBO calls it 'inexcusable and tasteless'|first=Martin|last=Pengelly|date=June 3, 2017|publisher=|via=The Guardian}} Following the episode, HBO sent a statement to media outlets, calling Maher’s remarks “inexcusable and tasteless” and said the cable network will remove that segment from future airings of the show.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/arts-and-entertainment/wp/2017/06/03/bill-maher-faces-calls-for-firing-after-using-the-n-word-on-his-hbo-show/|title=Bill Maher says he is ‘very sorry’ for using a racial slur on his HBO show|first1=Kristine|last1=Phillips|first2=Kristine|last2=Phillips|date=June 3, 2017|publisher=|via=washingtonpost.com}} Maher also issued a statement apologizing for the remarks. ===Political commentator=== Maher is a frequent commentator on various cable news networks, including [[CNN]], [[MSNBC]], [[Fox News]], and [[HLN (TV channel)|HLN]]. Maher has regularly appeared on CNN's ''[[The Situation Room with Wolf Blitzer]]''{{cite news |url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Zach-Galifianakis-Joint-1024995.aspx|title=Bill Maher: Zach Galifianakis Did Not Light Up a Real Joint|author=Robyn Ross |work=TV Guide}} and has also been a frequent guest on [[MSNBC]]'s ''[[Hardball with Chris Matthews]]'',{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/11366025/ns/msnbc_tv-hardball_with_chris_matthews|title=Bill Maher plays Hardball|publisher=MSN}} ''[[The Rachel Maddow Show (TV series)|The Rachel Maddow Show]]'',{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/huff-tv/arianna-hosts-the-irachel_b_144514.html|title=Arianna Hosts The Rachel Maddow Show with Guests Bill Maher, Lawrence O'Donnell, Nate Silver, Cory Booker and Google's Eric Schmidt|publisher=The Huffington Post | date=December 18, 2008}} and ''[[Countdown with Keith Olbermann]]''.{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/3036677/#40225161 |title=Maher on Countdown with Keith Olbermann (video) |publisher=MSNBC |date=January 21, 2011 |accessdate=November 7, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111106044244/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/3036677/ |archivedate=November 6, 2011 }} Maher has also appeared as a guest on [[HLN (TV channel)|HLN]]'s ''[[The Joy Behar Show]]''.{{cite news|url=http://joybehar.blogs.cnn.com/2010/09/28/bill-maher-spends-some-real-time-with-joy/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101002121611/http://joybehar.blogs.cnn.com/2010/09/28/bill-maher-spends-some-real-time-with-joy/|archivedate=2010-10-02|title=Bill Maher spends some real time with Joy|publisher=CNN}} He wrote the foreword for the 2002 book, ''Spin This!: All the Ways We Don't Tell the Truth'' by show host [[Bill Press]].''Spin This!: All the Ways We Don't Tell the Truth''; Bill Press; Simon & Schuster; 2002; Pg. xi Maher hosted the January 13, 2006 edition of ''[[Larry King Live]]'', on which he was a frequent guest. Maher appeared as a special guest on the June 29, 2010 edition of the show, on which CNN [[anchor]] [[Larry King]] announced his retirement.{{Cite news| url=http://www.mediaite.com/tv/bill-maher-helps-larry-king-say-goodbye/ | publisher=Mediaite | title=Bill Maher helps Larry King say goodbye | accessdate=August 9, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100706044557/http://www.mediaite.com/tv/bill-maher-helps-larry-king-say-goodbye/| archivedate= July 6, 2010 | deadurl= no}} Maher co-emceed the final show of ''[[Larry King Live]]'' on December 16, 2010 with [[Ryan Seacrest]].{{cite news |last=Rowe |first=Douglas J. |url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Larry-King-Ends-1026885.aspx |title=Surrounded by Famous Fans, Larry King Ends His 25-Year Run on CNN |work=TV Guide |date=December 16, 2010 |accessdate=November 7, 2011}} ===Other work=== In 2004 Maher appeared on stage as Satan in [[The Steve Allen Theater]] production of "Hollywood Hell House", a spoof of the Christian-run [[hell house]]s. The show was a faithful reproduction of an evangelistic scare-experience written by Reverend Keenan Roberts to terrify teenagers into declaring themselves Christians. "Our faith is that putting this up as itself, it will hoist itself on its own petard, that it's comical just as it is," explained producer Maggie Rowe. The show featured a rotating cast of over 160 celebrities, including [[Andy Richter]] (Jesus), [[Richard Belzer]], [[Dave Thomas (actor)|Dave Thomas]], [[Traci Lords]], [[Craig Bierko]], [[Sarah Silverman]], and [[Julia Sweeney]].{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/aug/22/entertainment/ca-artsnotes22.3|title=Scared straight to Hollywood|first=Lynne|last=Heffley|date=August 22, 2004|publisher=|via=LA Times}} Maher and director [[Larry Charles]] teamed up to make the movie ''[[Religulous]]'', described by trade publication ''Variety'' as a documentary "that spoofs religious extremism across the world". Also in 2013, Maher appeared on ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'' and offered to pay $5 million to a charity if [[Donald Trump]] would produce his [[birth certificate]] to prove that Trump's mother had not mated with an [[orangutan]].
